Package com.here.platform.location.core.geospatial.javadsl

Class GeoCoordinates<GC>

java.lang.Object
com.here.platform.location.core.geospatial.javadsl.GeoCoordinates<GC>
public class GeoCoordinates<GC> extends Object
Provides high-level operations on types representing geocoordinates.

    • getInstance

      public static <GC extends GeoCoordinateHolder> GeoCoordinates<GC> getInstance()
      Returns:
      A GeoCoordinates that provides functions for types implementing GeoCoordinateHolder

    • getInstance

      public static <GC> GeoCoordinates<GC> getInstance(GeoCoordinateAdapter<GC> geoCoordinateAdapter)
      Returns:
      A GeoCoordinates tailored for the types adapted by geoCoordinateAdapter

    • greatCircleDistanceMeters

      public double greatCircleDistanceMeters(GC p, GC q)
      Distance on the great-circle approximation of the Earth, between WGS84 coordinates, in meters

      The result is a Double representing the distance in meters between the two given points for which a GeoCoordinateOperations and a projection are defined.

      Parameters:
      p - The first point
      q - The second point
      Returns:
      The great-circle distance between p and q in meters

    • pointForFraction

      public GeoCoordinate pointForFraction(GC start, GC end, double fraction)
      Intermediate point at some fraction between two points on a great-circle in degrees.

      The result is a point between the two input points for which the distance from the start point is the given fraction of entire distance between the given start and end points.

      Parameters:
      start - The start point
      end - The end point
      fraction - In the range [0..1]
      Returns:
      A point between start and end point
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - When fraction is not in [0..1]

    • heading

      public double heading(GC start, GC end)
      Calculate Geodesic heading from one point to another on a great-circle.

      The result is a heading number in degrees where 0, 90, 180 and 270 mean North, East, South, and West, respectively.

      Parameters:
      start - the start point
      end - the end point
      Returns:
      a Double in the range [0..360).
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if start and end point are equal.
